column6: Disclosure Name
column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column6: Energy indirect (Scope 2) GHG emissions
column7: Transurban's scope 2 emissions in 2023 were 47,829 tCO2e.

column6: Other indirect (Scope 3) GHG emissions
column7: Transurban's scope 3 emissions in 2023 were 461,541 tCO2e.

column6: GHG emissions intensity
column13: Transurban recognises fleet managers' significant buying power and impact on the second-hand vehicle market each year by holding its first EV Drive Day in February. Transurban partnered with the Australasian Fleet Management Association and Origin Energy, where around 50 fleet managers learnt about the benefits of EVs and had the chance to test drive 16 models.
column20: EV Drive Day, Australasian Fleet Management Association, Origin Energy

column6: Reduction of GHG emissions
column13: In FY23, Transurban used 100% renewable electricity in its North American operations for the first time by purchasing and surrendering Renewable Energy Certificates from Oklahoma wind projects. Business-wide, 80% of Transurban's electricity was from renewable sources in FY23.
column20: Renewable Energy Certificate, wind project, renewable electricity

column6: Reduction of GHG emissions
column13: Truck-mounted attenuator (TMA) trucks protect the safety of road crews and motorists by providing a cushioned crash barrier to absorb the impact of collisions. These diesel vehicles spend significant time idling during traffic management activities. Transurban and Ventia have added an electric TMA to the NSW fleet Ã¢ÂÂ an Australian first Ã¢ÂÂ operating on Sydney's M2 since June 2023 to reduce these GHG emissions. This electric TMA is expected to save around 50 tonnes of GHG emissions yearly, compared to an equivalent diesel TMA.

column6: Emissions of ozone-depleting substances (ODS)
column7: This disclosure does not apply to Transurban.

column6: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
column7: Transurban emitted 134 tonnes of NOx in 2023.

column6: Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column13: Transurban's control room consolidation project in Queensland generated significant e-waste. Transurban engaged Circonomy, an Australian-based social enterprise, to sort and recycle or refurbish 100 computers, servers and monitors. By avoiding landfill, Transurban prevented the release of 40 tonnes of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: In May, Transurban began a three-month trial at its Brisbane corporate office to minimise waste being sent to landfills, including education sessions on recycling. Before the trial, an independent enterprise waste specialist assessed that 52% of Transurban's waste was being recycled. Each month, Transurban saw decreased waste going to landfills, and in the final month of the trial, it recorded 55.7% overall waste diverted from landfills. The trial results will help inform waste targets for other Transurban offices.

column6: Waste generated
column7: Transurban generated 13,344 tonnes of waste in 2023.

column6: Waste diverted from disposal
column7: Transurban recycled 6,542 tonnes of waste in 2023.

column6: Waste directed to disposal
column7: Transurban directed 6,802 tonnes of waste to landfill in 2023.

column6: Non-compliance with environmental laws and regulations
New suppliers that were screened using environmental criteria
column13: All suppliers are subject to Transurban's Supplier Sustainability Code of Practice (SSCoP), which includes environmental criteria. Suppliers applying for tenders managed by Transurban's sourcing team must complete 'returnable schedules', which include questions regarding the environmental performance of their goods and services.
column20: Supplier Sustainability Code of Practice, environmental criteria, returnable schedule

column6: Negative environmental impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column7: Transurban did not report this disclosure in FY23.

column6: New employee hires and employee turnover
Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
column8: Family and Domestic Violence paid leave
column13: This year, Transurban updated its family and domestic violence approach and now provides uncapped paid leave (over and above the local statutory entitlement of 10 days) to those who need it. Transurban also added more detail to its guidelines to define the personal safety plan support Transurban can provide to affected employees, for example, changing phone numbers at work sites and increasing security.
column20: Family and Domestic Violence, safety plan support, paid leave

column6: Parental leave
column13: Employees taking Parental Leave are entitled to 16 weeks of paid leave and up to 36 weeks of unpaid leave. In FY22, Transurban removed the distinction between primary and secondary carers in its Parental Leave Policy and extended the time employees can take their leave to 24 months after the birth or adoption of their child.
column20: Parental Leave Policy, paid leave, unpaid leave

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
column7: As per enterprise agreements and standard practice, Transurban notifies employees as soon as practicable after a decision is made that impacts working arrangements or employment, allowing a period for consultation with employees who may be adversely affected.

column6: Occupation health and safety management system
column13: Transurban's employees have Health, Safety and Environment (HSE) action plans that record activities to encourage accountability for a healthy and safe work environment, minimise environmental impacts, and continue building a positive HSE and Road Safety culture.
column20: HSE action plan, accountability, safe work environment

column6: Occupation health and safety management system
column13: The Board has ongoing commitment and oversight of Transurban's HSE and Road Safety Plan. The plan is centred on Transurban's long-term vision to achieve a future with zero life-changing injuries for employees, contractors and customers and minimising Transurban's impact on the environment.
column20: HSE and Road Safety Plans, long-term vision, zero injury

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: Transurban held a month of well-being events in Australia and North America, encouraging people to focus on their mental, physical and team well-being. Transurban targeted efforts to de-stigmatise well-being conversations and encouraged people to use EAP for preventative self-care.

column6: Occupational health services
column13: Transurban's employees have access to its employee assistance programs (EAP). These programs support people with proactive well-being strategies, including career coaching, financial well-being, or mental health concerns.
column20: Employee assistance program, well-being strategy, career coaching

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column13: In FY23, Transurban established core actions that all employees must complete over the year, including attending road safety events or webinars and having quarterly team HSE and road safety conversations. Transurban people must also include two additional actions aligned with their position: completing HSE site walks or undertaking specific online learning around HSE or road safety. Transurban encourages its people to record HSE observations proactively.
column20: Core action, road safety event, road safety conversation

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column13: Transurban recognised there were improvement opportunities around sharing safety learnings. Thus, in FY22, Transurban hosted a contractor safety forum for its various NSW-based contractors. The forum allowed industry professionals across Australia to meet face-to-face and discuss the continuous improvement of Transurban's industry's safety performance.
column20: Contractor safety forum, improvement opportunity, safety performance

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: In FY23, Transurban collaborated with Ability Works through its Inclusive Design service, which reviewed the design of its new Sydney office to provide recommendations on improving accessibility and inclusivity.

column6: Promotion of worker health
column13: In FY23, Transurban continued to promote physical activity and ergonomics, encouraging its people to seek early intervention and support for potential workplace injuries through its Fitness for Work team and injury management service provider.
column20: Fitness for Work team, injury management service, early intervention

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: Transurban offered free Headspace subscriptions for all employees since 2022. More than 800 employees have enrolled in this leading mindfulness app since its introduction.
